history.content:
If you mostly care about better understanding the math for Machine Learning, take EE 127 since applied linear algebra and optimization is the framework of many machine learning algorithms. 

Edit: Realized you already took 189

----------

Math 110 helps you understand the abstract aspect of lin alg but not really practical. 127 would be sufficient.

If you mostly care about better understanding the math for Machine Learning, take EE 127 since applied linear algebra and optimization is the framework of many machine learning algorithms. 

Edit: Realized you already took 189

----------

Math 110 helps you understand the abstract aspect of lin alg but not really practical. 127 would be sufficient.

If you mostly care about better understanding the math for Machine Learning, take EE 127 since applied linear algebra and optimization is the framework of many machine learning algorithms. 

Edit: Realized you already took 189
If you mostly care about prepping for CS 189, take EE 127 since applied linear algebra and optimization is the framework of many machine learning algorithms.

children.subject:
Hey Francie, nice to see you here again!

I agree that Math110 could build up the math maturity and linear algebra intuition, but I would still suggest taking 127 rather than 110 considering next semester's the poster's last semester. I'm taking 127 right now and I'm actually regretting that I took 110 last semester--I'd rather directly go into 127 for developing my machine learning skill. 

When I was taking 110, we didn't write out a single matrix; everything is about the operator. We spent a lot of time dealing with infinite sets and complex space. We didn't do determinant, trace, any matrix calculation; we discussed SVD for one lecture, no PCA at all. But of course, the situation would be completely different depending on the professor.

110 is indeed a fun class to take and have a lot of interesting proof, but those proof are somewhat different from the proof in ML classes like 16B, 126, 127. 127 has a lot of hard-core algebraic based proof too.

It surprises me that you didn't discuss the determinant or trace in 110. 110 is the perfect place to learn how to actually prove properties of the determinant and trace without these extremely messy, tedious, and unmotivated matrix calculations!

I think Math110 must be professor dependent then. My semester discussed trace/determinant etc. We did cover some stuff that I've never seen elsewhere, such as adjoint transformations, but all topics were helpful in developing the "mindset" of a mathematician.

Different perspective here:

While the content of Math110 is less "practical" as some may say because you can't take a topic and immediately apply it to whatever machine learning gizmo you're working on, it was a crucial class for me to develop my linear algebra intuition. 

I took Math110 and then 127+189 in the following semester and I wouldn't have been able to succeed in the latter classes without the strong foundational base in Math110. In my experience, 127+189 assumed the comfort with linear algebra that only comes from a semester of Math110.  

Math54 is an extremely computational class -  how to multiply matrices, how to invert matrices, how to diagonalize matrices. While Math110 covers some similar topics as Math 54 (and then some different stuff at the end) - there is almost no computation. Instead of calculating an inverse, you prove something about an inverse. And in my experience, the homeworks I had in 110 did a phenomenal job of "building" your proof writing abilities - starting with small, manageable proofs and then building up to something larger, which really gets you comfortable writing proofs (of any kind - this is helping me in math104 at the moment). In contrast, my experience with 70 proofs is just being tossed into the deep end with less good effect. 

TBH if you have the space, I think both Math110 and EE127 would be valuable. Math110 will give you strong linear algebra and math writing intuition, and then 127 is a great course to see how you can use your linear algebra intuition to apply to optimization/machine learning contexts. If I'd had to choose one though, I would say 110. 127 without a strong foundational knowledge would mean some of the cool nuances would be lost simply trying to keep up with the material.

history.content:
I am a graduating senior and planning schedule for my final semester. I am debating whether to take MATH 110 to strengthen linear algebra or not. Can someone who has taken MATH 110 share the experience of it? Ex. how much content does it cover beyond MATH 54? Does it help you be really familiar with the proofs? I took 189 last year and found that I was not very comfortable with proofs, does MATH 110 help with that? Thx so much!

Or does EECS 127 provide more practice of linear algebra proofs used in 189?
history.subject: How useful is MATH 110?
